cab.content: i^llOocument is the Property of /His CnianET.[i^Li^i^s GovernmentMINISTRY OF FOOD.c ...t for Week ending Wednesday, October 2, 1918.PART I.-ACTION TAKEN.Food Council. A meeting of the Council was held on Tuesday, October 1st, Mr. Clynes in the chair.Mr. Beveridge reported that Captain Tallents had been charged with the preparation of a scheme of milk control and distribution. A re-allocation of the winter prices of milk charged to retailers was agreed to by the Council.A resolution of the Home Supplies Board on the subject of home cereals prices for .1919 was considered and it was decided that Mr. Wise should bring the matter before the Joint Officials Committee.Sir Alan Anderson reported that in view of the reduced imports programme it was not considered necessary to proceed with the provision of 5 million cubic feet of cold storage of the 8 million proposed to be built on Government account. It would probably be necessary to construct an insulated store of 3,000,000 cubic feet at Liverpool, but the difficulty was one of transport rather than of storage, and the Port and Transit Corporation were being asked to state a case for submission to the Priority Committee of the War Cabinet.Sir John Beale reported that the Imports Board would take charge of cabling and that Sir William Goode had therefore been invited to join the Board. This decision was approved.Mr. Wise reported that the proposed scheme for rationing feeding-stuffs had been discussed with Sir Daniel Hall and that the Board of Agriculture was favourable, and would appoint a representative on the Allocation Committee. It was proposed that the Chief Live Stock Commissioner should supervise the scheme, which would be worked through the Live Stock Commissioners with the help of local Farmers' Committees approved by the Board of Agriculture.The Imports Board. The first meeting of the Board was held on September 27th, Sir John Beale in the chair.v It was agreed that the Board should act as the " opposite number " of the Allied Provisions Export Commission and the British Ministry of Food in U.S.A., and should ,be the sole channel of cable communication with those organisations and with other agencies of the Ministry abroad for the purchase of commodities other than cereals and sugar.While the detailed work of purchases will be left to the Supply Divisions as at present the Director of Imports will be fully informed of purchases made, progress of deliveries and shipments,, and will be supplied with such other information as may be found necessary so that the Board may be satisfied that the whole business in con-nection with imports of the Ministry is properly conducted.All cables from and to all parts of the world dealing with purchases on British account or in connection with any purchase will come before the Board.Full statements will be prepared for the Board showing the position as to shipping, imports, requirements, and stocks, and the Board will be responsible for ascertaining through its officers that the necessary imported supplies required by the Supply Sections, for the maintenance of the rations or of supplies at the agreed rate, are being purchased, brought forward and shipped at proper dates.The Board will also ascertain that the Financial Branch is fully informed of the progress of purchases and that the necessary financial sanctions have been or are being obtained.Meetings of the Board will be held daily at 11.0 a.m. until further notice.Home Supplies Board. The first meeting of the Board was held on Thursday, September 26th, Mr. Beveridge in the chair.A scheme for the rationing of feeding-stuffs was considered by the Board. The scheme had been approved by the Committee of the Agricultural Advisory Council appointed to consider the question and by the Joint Officials Committee. It wasA (33)6038-1 Pkl 140 10/18 E k S 2agreed in view of the urgency of the situation with regard to feeding-stuffs, that the scheme should be pressed forward with the utmost rapidity.It was decided that the Board should meet once, a week on Thursday at 5.30 p.m. Additional meetings may be called on Mondays at 4.0 p.m.The Central Agricultural Advisory Council. At the meeting of the Council, which was held on the 1st October 1918, the question of how to deal with the large number of cattle now being sent to market at the end of the grass season, especially in the north of England, was discussed ; it was stated that a serious situation had arisen since the railway strike took place at the time that these large numbers of cattle were being sent to market, and it had been extremely difficult to dispose of them ; there are no sufficient facilities for freezing meat in this country, and the question of labour for slaughtering is a very difficult one at present.A resolution was passed urging the Ministry of Food to * put at once into consumption or cold storage all stock really fit for slaughter, and to raise the price of cattle at the rate of Is. per cwt. per week from the 1st November onwards, with a corresponding increase in the price of sheep, to compensate the farmer for keeping on all the stock he can possibly hold, and to arrange at once for the release and distribution of a certain quantity of cattle cake, in order that stock may be kept fit during the winter and conserved until the spring.The scheme for the distribution and rationing of cattle feeding-stuffs was again discussed and read. After the meeting of the Council had been concluded, the Sub-Committee which had been appointed for the purpose, went through with the officials concerned, the draft form of application, and the proposed scale of rations for the various classes of stock ; these were agreed to by the Sub-Committee.Consumers' Council. A meeting of this Council was held on Wednesday, October 2nd, Mr. Clynes in the chair. Mr. Hyndman moved :-" That in view of the Order increasing the price of milk to the farmers to - 2s. od. per gallon, which necessitates large increases in the price of butter and cheese, while bringing the. retail price of milk up to no less than lOd. per ' quart in the cities, the Consumers' Council calls upon the Government to use our public funds for the maintenance of the retail price of milk during the coming winter at not more than 6c?. per quart, and further demands that ! similar steps be taken in regard to the price of butter and cheese." Meanwhile, the Consumers' Council urges upon the Government the necessity for the immediate enforcement of the measures already sanctioned by the Ministry of Food to ensure an adequate supply of milk at the charge of the State and the municipalities and other public bodies for nursing mothers as well as for all children up to the age of five years."After considerable discussion the resolution was put to the vote in two parts, the first part of the resolution was lost, the second part was carried unanimously.The National Kitchens Movement. -The movement is showing signs of substantial progress in the provinces where some of the large towns have established kitchens, or are about to do so. Rotherham are opening one of the finest kitchens in the county, Ossett another. Yorkshire town opened their first kitchen in the town hall to-day.Leicester have decided to take over nine large coffee-houses, which are assessed at over 2,0001. These coffee-houses' are paying their way, and the' rentals which the Leicester Council are to pay to the local company will be well covered "by income, and little capital outlay involved. This scheme provides for the centre of the town, or the inner ring as it is described. The outer ring is still to be provided for. This can only be done by using Sunday Schools. The Leicester Committee think that as there are so few premises available (a complaint which exists in nearly every district in the country) the Department should obtain powers to commandeer. In nearly every district the National Kitchens movement is handicapped for want of compulsory powers to acquire property.Coventry are putting their scheme a very excellent one into operation next week. Ripon have approved the principle and are establishing a scheme. Richmond, which has several kitchens, are to add to their number. Derby are to add two excellent kitchens. Preston have taken a shop as a National Kitchen on a five years' agreement. Hull is moving rapidly ahead with a large scheme, and it seems as 3257though Yorkshire would have a record number of kitchens for a single county within two months. Lancashire has shown signs of improvement, and before Christmas there should be excellent developments in this county. Glasgow are to establish four National Kitchens in good shops.American Meat Packers.It is understood that all the Government authorities of the United States have accepted the first three recommendations of the Federal Trade Commission on the Packers, and that they have joined in advising the President to take that course. The recommendations are: (1) The Government acquisition of all stock cars, that is the cars in which live animals are transported.(2) The Government operation of stock yards, - - (3) The Government acquisition of, and operation of, all refrigerator cars.It should be noted that by the Presidents proclamation of June 20th, 1918, the stock yards and packers were only authorised to carry on business under license to be granted under the provision of the American Food Act. The proclamation became operative on July 25th.The Federal Trade Commission, in their report, laid great stress upon the assertion that the five great American packing concerns, even if they owned no packing plants and killed no cattle, would still be equally strong on account of their ownership of the railroad stock and refrigerated cars and other means of. transportation and distribution. The contention of the Federal Trade Commission is that Government acquisition of the railroad cars will enable healthy competition between all the packing interests of the United States, and thus destroy the monopoly of the five great packers. The profits of the larger packers are already limited to considerably less than one-halfpenny per pound upon their animal products.Supplies and Prices.Bacon, Rams and Lard. Alterations in the constitution of the Bacon Advisory Committee are under consideration with a view to making the Committee more representative of the trade as a whole and avoiding over-representation of a particular branch.The decision to reduce the imports of lard will make it impossible to supply manufacturers as had been originally intended.Cheese. -Shipments from New Zealand are coming forward according to require-ments.A further shipment of 246 crates of Canadian cheese ex S.S. "City of Vienna" stranded off Halifax has been made. A small supply of cheese is still coming forward from the United States of America.Cocoa. The lists of raw cocoa available for distribution sent in by the grading committees amount to 10,723 bags. .At the request of the Foreign Office 2,600 tons of raw cocoa discharged from four Dutch ships, which were requisitioned by the Ministry of Shipping in the early part of the year, have been requisitioned by the Ministry, and will be graded and put into distribution forthwith.Coffee. The Admiralty Marshal, with the support of this Ministry, is making application to the Acting President of the Prize Court for orders for sale in respect of 100,000 bags of coffee seized as prize. If the order is made, the Marshal, on instructions from this Ministry, will be able to keep the market -supplied throughout the winter months when the demand on coffee is at its greatest.Dried Fruits. The prices fixed by the Mesopotamia authorities for Persian dates are so excessive (being nearly double those of last'year) that it is not proposed at present to make any purchases. The S.S. " Emanuel" with about 4,000 tons of Greek currants has reached Liverpool. Further shipments are reported of Californian and Indian sultanas.Meat. The particular difficulty of the situation at the moment arises from the fact that more cattle are coming forward to the markets than can be absorbed'by the ration on its present scale. This tends to create some small feeling of resentment in some districts that the ration should have been reduced at this particular juncture, but this feeling is by: no means general. On the. other band, pther grounds for complaint have been entirely removed by the cessation of the issue of frozen meat and the supply of the full ration allowance in home-killed, meat In order to deal with the t4surplus of cattle, arrangements have just been completed under which the Army in the United Kingdom will be furnished with home-killed meat. These arrangements will come into operation on Monday next, and it is anticipated that for the next four or five weeks at least the Army can be fed entirely on home-killed meat. This course should have the double advantage of absorbing the surplus cattle and of enabling the Army to build up to some extent the desired reserve stocks of frozen meat. It must still be emphasised that farmers are alarmed at receiving no assurances that feeding-stuffs will be available for them in the winter months, and this in a large measure explains the present rush to the markets. The absence of any inducement to keep back their stock may seriously affect the situation in the early part of next year, as the estimates of home-grown, meat to come forward in these months are not likely to be realised.The rigour with which the meat rationing Orders have been applied to the metropolitan area is now being extended to other parts of the country, and it is expected that this will bring the actual consumption into closer relation with the amount of the permitted ration.Food Prices. Considerable complaint is arising among Food Control Committees, Labour bodies, and from the general public, with regard to the increasing price of foodstuffs generally, and more particularly the increase in the price of milk, Govern-ment butter, and meat. The present price of fresh eggs and fruit also occasion considerable criticism.Divisional Reports.Scotland West. It is reported that since venison was made coupon free, additional quantities have come into the'market, and that it has met with a ready sale at prices varying from Sd. to Is. Id. a lb.The Midlands-It is reported that at a demonstration recently held at Birmingham, at which practically all forms of war industry were represented, the exhibit of the Local Food Control Committee attracted considerable attention. Two lorries depicted the conditions prevailing in England and Germany respectively. On the one was a fine display of bread, bacon, ham, potatoes, &c, all marked " Coupon Free." On the other, milk, potatoes, cheese, bread, coffee and clothing were shown with the number of coupons required for their purchase, attached to each. The exhibit strikingly emphasised the disparity existing between the two countries after four years of war.Two very successful exhibitions have been organised at Leeds and Sheffield, in connection with the Allotment Holders' Association, which, with Professor Thompsons exhibits of food values, and practical demonstrations in fruit bottling and drying, arranged by Representatives of the Ministry of Food, are said to have proved a valuable aid to propaganda work.Enforcement of Orders.The total number of prosecutions for the week is 575, 83 less than in the previous week. The number of convictions is 529.The number of Orders in respect of which prosecutions were instituted was 62 ; the principal Orders being : Prosecutions. Convictions.Rationing ----- 63 62Bread - - - - - 49 45Flour Restriction (Ireland) -. - - 45 41Tea (Retail) Prices - - - - 37 30 'Soft Fruit (Sales) - - ... 36 36The average fine for England, Scotland and Wales has risen considerably (by 21. 4*. Id.) owing to somewhat heavy fines inflicted under the Bread Order and the Rationing Order.Orders under Defence of the .Realm Regulations. . The Public Meals (Ireland) Order, 1918, dated 21st September 1918, lays down certain regulations and restrictions for all public eating-places in Ireland^ other than canteens under the control of the Navy and Army Canteen Board.Imported Onions Order, 1918, dated September 25th, 1918, controls the price of onions imported into this country and fixes maximum wholesale and retail prices. No imported onions shall be sold in the first instance, except by a licensed dealer, and 2585the sale by retail is prohibited except by a registered retail dealer in potatoes. Certain restrictions are imposed on sales by brokers and wholesale dealers.The Jam and'Syrup (Registration of Dealers) Order, 1918, dated September 26th, 1918, provides for the licensing of dealers in jam or in syrup.. The Margarine (Prices) (Ireland) Order, 1918, dated 27th. September 1918, fixes maximum wholesale and retail prices for margarine in Ireland. The retail price is to be Is. 2d. per lb.The Potatoes (Export from Ireland) Order'(No. 2), 1918, dated 27th September 1918, prohibits any person, except under licence, from consigning or shipping any potatoes of the 1918 crop from Ireland to any destination outside Ireland.The Pig (Sales) Order, 1918, dated 27th September 1918, provides that pigs sold for slaughter must be sold in a market to a Government buyer at the controlled price. An exception is made in favour of the small owner, i.e., one who owns and sells for slaughter not more than three pigs in any year, and owners of pigs may be specially authorised to send their pigs direct to bacon factories. The maximum price remains the same except that a per head charge will be made to cover the cost of transport and distribution. The Order brings the sale of pigs for slaughter under the same, control as the sale of cattle and sheep. - (! ,., ;The British-made Butter (Restriction) Order, 1918, dated 28th September 1918, introduces a new scheme for the distribution of butter, and restricts the purchases of British-made butter by retailers, caterers, and institutions. Purchases willbe permissible only on a permit form from. Local Food Control Committees, and'the retailer's allowance of British-made and Government butter will not exceed 2 6zs. per week per registered customer.Order amending the Milk (Winter Prices) Order, 1918, dated 30th September 1918, substitutes the following maximum prices for those fixed by the Milk (Winter Prices) Order, 1918, on a sale by a wholesaler, when delivery, is made to the buyers' premises,: . .;2s. l\d. from October 1st to 7th.2s. Qd. from October 8th to November 21st.2s. l\d. from November 22nd to December 16th.2s. 8cl. from December 17th to April 30th.The Intoxicating Liquor (Output and Delivery) (Ireland) Order, 1918, dated 30th September 1918, lays down certain conditions for the supply of beer to license holders in Ireland by the- wholesalers, with. a view to the more equitable distribution of beer in the country.British'Onions Order, 1918, dated 1st October 1918, fixes the maximum price of British eating and pickling onions of the 1918 crop on a gradually ascending scale from October 1918 to April 1919. Eating onions are those which will not pass through a II" mesh, and pickling onions are smaller ones. Onions must be sold by weight, eating onions must not be used for pickles, nor must British onions be mixed with imported onions.PART IT-SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION.. The greater consumption of bread and flour, to which special attention was directed in last week s Report, appears (from the enlarged issues to retailers) to be increasing:' 'The rise in prices is attracting attention and in certain localities is leading to grave, discontent. L . . 6Imports.The improvement in total imports, indicated in last week's Report, has not been m^Dedrr&e,total ,weight, of,ltthe principal foods and feeding-stuffs imported: falling from 205,700 to 164,200 tons. During the first four weeks of the new cerealJS 6638-1 " M u c - ' -P. 6year the imports generally have been less than last year, due mainly to the reduced import of barley, oats, and maize, as will be seen in the following table :-September Imports (4 weeks). 1917. 1918. Increase or Decrease. 1917. 1918. Increase or Decrease. Tons. Tons. Tons. Tons. Tons. . Tons.Total - - 804,300 684,800 1 - 119,500- Lard 1,900 12,600 -r 10,700Wheat - 220,100 298,200 + 78,100 Butter - 4,800 3,800 - 1,000'Flour - 66,200 59,200 - 7,000 Margarine 2,400 * - - 2,400Equivalent in 307,100 372,000 4- 64,900 Cheese - 14,600 16,000 -f 1,400Grain. Condensed milk 5,500 18,500 -f 13,000Barley, oats, 220,500 82,100 - 138,400 Sugar 161,000 98,700 - 62,300and maize. Tea - 5,600 8,800 -H 3,200Rice 41,900 800 -'. 41,100 Coffee - 500 800 + 300Meat 39,400 32,900 - 6,500 Cocoa - 1,300 6,200 4- 4,900Bacon - ; - 18,600 46,200 -f 27,600 Compared with the previous week there was, in the week ended 28th September, a slight rise in wheat but a fall in wheaten flour, the imports in equivalent grain (98,200 tons) being 15,000 tons lower. They were, however, very much higher than in the corresponding week of 1917 (61,200 tons). No rice arrived, and very little maize (1,300 tons). Bacon imports recovered somewhat, but the quantity (9,000 tons) is insufficient to meet current consumption. Beef and mutton dropped back from 13,300 tons to 4,400 tons ; but canned and other meat (3,700 tons) was above the average. There was a good import of lard (4,200 tons) and of condensed milk (3,600 tons), but butter (1,200 tons) and cheese (1,760 tons) were below the average. Sugar imports, which were up to the average in the previous week (26,900 tons) fell to 15,800 tons ; the imports a year ago were 55,400 tons. There was a larger import of tea (5,700 tons). Imports of coffee and cocoa were small, and the totals for the first nine months of the year have been far below those of the corresponding nine months of 1917.Consumption.. Bread and Flour. The marked increase in consumption for the four weeks ended September 14th (Table E) was emphasised in last week's Report. As compared with the four previous weeks the increase amounted to 4 per cent., and as compared with the corresponding period in 1917, to at least 10 per cent. The index number is now higher than it has been at any time since the record commenced in April 1916, with the exception of March 1917, when, however, there was a shortage of potatoes.Another index of consumption is provided by the deliveries of flour from mills plus the imported flour issued direct to agents. The average weekly supplies during four weeks ended August 17th were 91,100, August 24th 92,700, August 31st 95,200, September 7th 102,800, September 14th 104,500, and September 21st 105,500 tons. This steady increase confirms the conclusion reached on the basis of the bakers' returns, and carries it to a later date.To some extent the increased consumption represents a normal seasonal variation, but it is also no doubt due to the improved palatableness of the loaf, and suggests that the need for strict economy is being less.generally recognised.Meat. Supplies of cattle at markets increased by a further 17 per cent, while sheep fell off slightly (Table C). The rate in both cases is approximately equal to that of September last year. The weight of meat produced, however, is less, and the total supply of home-fed butcher's meat of all kinds in Great Britain for the week, estimated at 19,400 tons, is about 20 per cent, less than the weekly rate for September of last year. , Issues of refrigerated meat fell to 3,600 tons. Owing to difficulties of transport, it will remain necessary to feed part of the population on imported meat even when home supplies become sufficient to meet the demands of the ration.Milk. The index number of milk carried by the principal railways is falling, steadily, but not out of proportion to the normal seasonal deliveries, and the September, 1918, index is above that of September, 1917. The latest live stock estimates for Great Britain show a satisfactory increase in the dairy herd, and the number of new animals added to the herd indicates the confidence of the farmer in the future of the dairy industry. As in the case of meat, however, mere numbers will avail nothing if sufficient feeding-stuffs are not obtainable; : Fish. Weekly arrivals of fish at Billingsgate and at several provincial markets in recent weeks show a steady decline. As compared with a weekly average of 4,061 tons for August, the figures for recent weeks are as follows : September 7th, September Mth. September 21st. Tons. Tons. Tons.Billingsgate - 2,055 1,843 1,732Other markets - 1,516 1,444 1,281Total - 3,571 .. 3,287 3,013Stocks.During the third week of September stocks of meat and provisions have undergone few important changes. There has been a fall of 2,000 tons in the stock of mutton, compensated by a rise of 2,200 tons in beef, a fall of 2,000 tons in bacon, and a further fall of 2,200 tons in butter. There has been a continued increase in the stocks of condensed milk due to the policy of the Ministry in building up a reserve in anticipa-tion of the milk position in the coming winter. The stocks held by the Ministry now amount to 34,000 tons. Other Ministry stocks include bacon 62,500 tons, refrigerated meat 15,200 tons (apart from 5,200 tons held by the Board of Trade for civilian consumption), canned meat 10,000 tons, cheese 14,700 tons, butter 10,400 tons, lard 20,200 tons, and rabbits 4,000 tons. (N.B.-Certain figures appearing in last week's Report (Table F) have been amended to include a larger number of ware-houses.), Prices.Recent variations in prices relate principally to meat a'nd milk. Retail meat prices were increased by 2d. a lb., on September 22nd, the corresponding wholesale prices of beef increasing from 114s. 4d to 133s., and of mutton from 121s. 4d. to 140.";. per rcwt. Retail milk prices were increased on October 1st from Sd. to 9d. a quart, plus Id. per quart if delivered in bottles, provided the milk is bottled under proper sanitary conditions. 8Table A.-Imports of Principal Food and Feeding Stuffs.so y$*?':' Average Weekly Net Iraports* in 1913.
